title: 109_s1050
content: The Act titled "Expedited Remedy for Persistent Dumping Act of 2005" provides an expedited remedy for cases of persistent dumping. The "Expedited Remedy for Persistent Dumping Act of 2005" amends the Tariff Act of 1930 to initiate expedited antidumping duty investigations within 20 days of a request from an interested party if imports of a particular class of merchandise have increased materially from an additional supplier country. The "Expedited Remedy for Persistent Dumping Act of 2005" allows for expedited antidumping duty investigations if imports of merchandise from an additional supplier country have increased materially. The "Expedited Remedy for Persistent Dumping Act of 2005" allows for expedited antidumping duty investigations if imports have increased by 15 percent or more over a comparable period preceding the initiation of the antidumping investigation. The Act also outlines procedures and injury determinations for expedited investigations. The "Expedited Remedy for Persistent Dumping Act of 2005" allows for expedited antidumping duty investigations. Section 735 applies to expedited investigations, with a preliminary determination issued within 80 days. The Commission must determine material injury within 45 days of receiving a request. The Commission will determine material injury within 45 days of receiving a request, using reasonably available information. If there is a reasonable indication of material injury and an affirmative final determination, a final determination will be made within 120 days. The administering authority makes affirmative preliminary and final determinations within specific timeframes. An affirmative final determination is based on factors determining material injury to the US industry due to imports of subject merchandise. The administering authority makes affirmative final determinations based on factors determining material injury to the US industry due to imports of subject merchandise. The imports of the subject merchandise are not negligible. The Tariff Act of 1930 is amended to include reimbursement of duties based on dumping margins and countervailable subsidies, unless importers can prove they were not reimbursed for any antidumping or countervailing duties paid. The amendments made by this Act shall apply to goods from Canada and Mexico.
